The experiences of groups drawn from the ranks of the same formal organiza¬
tion were varied. In general, however, these groups lacked the intensity of in¬
volvement of the friendship groups and their discussions tended to drag. There were
several outstanding groups in this category, however.
No attempt was made to organize groups under trained leaders and open to
the general public in meeting places such as schools. These so-called ”cross-
sectional groups” rarely are that, Where they appear to be, case studies have shown
they ccrne chiefly from one social level with persons from other levels usually turn¬
ing out to be social isolates more interested in being with pe ople than in the actual
subject of discussion.
While variables other than the organizing principle affected the success of
all groups, some important inferences from the disparity between these three kinds
of groups can be made. Sweeping generalizations on the basis of this one experience,
of course, would be unwise, but these factors should be considered in planning future
programs of this kind:
!'• In friendship groups, there is a feeling of freedom and tolerance which
frequently is h. eking in other groups. People relax more easily with each other and
talk more readily about controversial subjects. Members of this kind of group can be
brought together more easily. Intellectual exercise becomes an enjoyable pastime,-
Research has also shown that fundamental attitude changes are more likely to occur
in this kind of group than in others; for opinion tends to be a group product,,
shared by all group members, and a shift in the group norm is likely to be followed
by shifts in individual opinion.
